HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 9, 1927

COMMITTEE CLEARS
ON RECENT RAFFLE
Twenty-five dollars was
cleared by the 1928 June
Week Committee from the
proceeds of the raffle held recently, stated David Kaufman,
treasurer of the committee.
Fifty-five dollars in chances
were sold, and expenses totalled thirty dollars.
Several more raffles will be
held this year. The idea is
not so much to make money as
to keep up the interest of the
undergraduates in June Week.
The next chances will probably be sold after the Christmas holidays.

BASKETBALL MEETING
IS WELL ATTENDED
48 Candidates Sign up for New
Winter Sport; Schedule
Being Arranged
Forty-eight candidates for Hopkins' latest sport turned out at the
basketball organization meeting held
Tuesday in the Mechanical Engineering Hall. Speeches and a discussion of prospects for a success
ful season formed the program.
Dr. Van Orman, Gardner Mallonee, and Fred Bauernschmidt addressed the candidates. Mallonee
stressed the fact that .the team must
be supported, or else this year will
be the last for the winter sport.
Basketball is merely being tried this
year, and the support of the entire
student body is necessary to make it
permanent.
The names of candidates for the
team as well as those who are out
for manager were taken. Nearly
fifty men signed up• for the team;
seven signified their intention of trying for the managership.
It is planned tentatively to play
games on Tuesday and Friday evenings. The season, it is expected,
will open sometime in January.

VAN ORMAN DENIES
CORNELL PROPOSAL
Dr. Ray Van Orman will
not leave Hopkins to coach
football at Cornell next year.
Several days ago a rumor that
he might accept an offer on
the part of the Ithacans to
coach the Red team was circulated by the Baltimore
News.
When questioned concerning the rumor, Van Orman
emphatically denied having
been approached or . having
considered any such proposal.
"You know as much about it
as I do," he said.

NEW PLAN AFFECTS
YEAR'S ENROLLMENT
College and Business School
Lose; Engineers Gain

OLD OPPONENTS
ON '28 SCHEDULE
Swarthmore and Randolph-Macon
Placed on List
WILL PLAY EIGHT GAMES
Jays Will Not Meet Delaware or
Loyola, However
Swarthmore and Randolph-Macon will replace Loyola and Delaware on the 1928 football schedule.
According to an announcement
made by Frederick Bauernschmidt,
manager of football, eight games
will be played.
Randolph-Macon and Swarthmore have both been met on the
gridiron in former years. No postseason contests are scheduled. The
complete 1928 schedule appears for
the first time as follows:
Richmond First

With the release by the Registrar's Office of the number of registrations made on the opening days
of the University this year, some interesting facts have come to light.
The enrollment is smaller this
year than last in the School of
Business Economics. and the College of Arts and Sciences, appreciably so in the latter. The New
Plan, no doubt, is the cause of the
decrease in the College enrollment.
While last year was one of high enrollment in the Economics Department, because of the closing of that
same branch at the University of
Maryland, it is only natural that
there should be something of a decrease this year.
The School of Engineering, however, was able to show a substantial
increase in the number of enrollments over those of last year, there
being no causes but those of natural
growth affecting it at this time.
The Faculty of Philosophy also
shows quite an upward trend in the
number of members_ enrolled, many
of them having been gained at the
expense of the College of Arts and
Sciences through the New Plan.
Many Southerners Of the entire membership of the
Faculty of Philosophy, 70 per cent
are from Southern States, 18 per
cent from Northern and Western
States and the remaining 12 per
cent from foreign countries, ranging from Poland and Russia
through Palestine and South Africa
to China.
But 4 per cent of the undergraduates studying in the School of
Business Economics are from the
North, and no foreigners are present.
In the College of Arts and Sciences, 77 per cent come from the
South, 20 per cent from the North
and West and 3 per cent are foreigners. The Engineers have a
great number of students from below the Mason-Dixon Line, 93 per
cent of the entire number being
from the South, 5 per cent coming
from the North and West, and the
remaining 2 per cent coming from
outside the United States.

It is to be hoped that the loss of
Mallonee, Boynton, Biddison, Kaufman, Strader, Leibensperger, Lawrence, Pindell, Dotterweich, Schmiedicke and Ahroon will not prevent
the next football season from being

A. A. Board Makes
30 Athletic Awards
Thirty athletic awards were made
by the Athletic Board in recognition of services rendered during the
past two months. Fourteen varsity
"H's" for football, ten "aHa's" for
football, and six "cHc's" for members of the cross-country team were
made.
Captain Mallonee, Leibensperger,
Kaufman, Biddison, Kegan, Houston, Strade.r, Boynton, Lyons, Lawrence, Caplan, Pindell, Ahroon and
Schmiedicke are the men who received the varsity "H" for football.
The letter was awarded to Ahroon
and Schmiedicke as recognition of
their faithful services during the
past four seasons. Neither of these
men had played a sufficient amount
of time to be awarded a letter on
that basis; but their loyalty and
spirit was such that, on the strong
recommendation of both Dr. Van
Orman and Captain Mallonee, the
Athletic Association Board awarded
them the major "H.!'
Minor Awards

The men receiving the "aHa" for
football are: Keating, Love, Hershey, Bledsoe, Kaufholz, Devereux,
Johnson, Boyd, Dotterweich and
Powell. This award is given to the
men who have participated in a few
games but who have not played a
sufficient length of time to win the
major "H."
Captain Schiebel, Gwinn, Kelly,
Waters, Wheeler and Emerson are
the men who won the "cHc" for
their endeavors on the cross-country team. The election of Robert
Kelly as captain of the cross-country team for the 1928 season was
officially recognized by the Board.
The new record for the Homewood
course, of 22 minutes, 59 seconds,
set by Dick Gwinn, was also given
official sanction.

DO THEY REALLY WANT BASKETBALL?
If the number of candidates for basketball is indicative of anything, the team should get off to a good start. Of course, the fact
that some fifty men are hopeful of making the team does hot
necessarily mean that there will be even five excellent basketball
players among the lot, but it does mean, we believe, that the
student body wants basketball.
Now, whether the team will receive the "moral" support of
the student body at the games is a problem that is probably keeping some of our alumni awake at nights. Will the games be
well attended? Would the sport prosper, though, if the team
should lose its first two or three games? The opinion has been
expressed on the campus that the success of the team, as far as
the support of the student body is concerned, depends upon its
winning the first few games. If it appears as though the team
will be a good one, it is argued, the fickle student body will
support it; if not, there will be little or no interest evinced in it.
We want to .warn against this point of view before it gains
headway. Of course, we like to be optimistic, but it can hardly
be expected that a team organized for the first time, and, moreover,
comparatively late in the season, will win the State championship.
If it wins more than half of its games, it will be doing exceedingly well. We hope, therefore, that the apparent enthusiasm for
the new sport is not caused merely by the novelty. Though there
are no goal posts to tear down, there are still ways of supporting
a team.

A Nice New Car

Moods.
We all have them—dark, gray,
sullen, sour, light, merry, funereal.
They come and go unheralded and
in no particular order. They are
miscellaneous.
So with the Hopkins campus.
Like humans, its moods are manifold, and Gilman Hall, not yet old
enough to wear the unruffled dignity
of venerable aristocracy, readily reflects the changes in temperament.
On windy days in autumn the
campus takes on a frolicsome air
It radiates mischief. Leaves, crisp
and sere, scurry pell mell in high
glee before the wind. Whole battalions of them race about like mad
in ecstatic confusion. Pieces of
paper and other movab!es, lying
about, abrubtly come to life and
dance about in frisky fashion. Little whirlwinds and eddies of air
suddenly spring up and go gamboling off into nothingness. And the
chimes in Gilman tower ring with
a merrier note as roguish blasts play
outlandish pranks with fall styles
in co-ed apparel.
Sometimes the spirit of the campus is dull—duller than dirt, full of
dusty answers. Such is its complexion on a steaming day in midsummer, when inactivity charges
the very atmosphere with stolid oppression. The face on the clock
looks bored and somehow at a loss.
Often the change in mood on
such days is sudden. A thunderstorm gathers in the west and begins to descend like a scourge, whipping things into action as it comes.
The air suddenly bristles with energy, becomes electric. The tower
looks frightened, standing sharp out
in startling relief against the menacing gun metal hue of the clouds.
Inertia gives place to taut expectancy, as a distant rumbling rolls
a warning. The storm breaks and
Homewood quivers under the lash
of rain and lightning. Thus quickly
in life may dullness change to action.
Oftentimes, on cold rainy days,
the lead of the skies sinks its heavy
pall, and gloom sits brooding on
the chimney tops of Gilman Hall.
Slow, drizzling rain falls in mournful silence and black depression
reigns in sad state, like a corpse in
evening dress.
Such conventional moods at

Homewood are well known and frequent. It remains for a sleet storm,
such as the recent phenomenon, to
make the campus temporarily a
region of rare fantastic loveliness.
All day last Sunday rain and
sleet had fallen and accumulated
in freezing, so that by evening
Homewood shone with an eerie and
amazing beauty. The warm light
within the clock tower of Gilman
Hall partially illuminated the flashing ice-glazed front of the building and shed a soft reflection out
on the smooth, glassy surface of the
quadrangle.
The campus became a wonderland of crystal, in which every object, however small, received its individual coating of ice. Railings,
door-knobs, the iron grating of the
gates of Gilman tunnel, the posts,
the steps—all shared in the general
transformation.
Smooth sheets of silver marked
the location of the tennis courts,
and the wire fences enclosing them
were networks of crystal.
The hedges, gleaming under the
boardwalk lamps, turned countless
leaves of clearest glass to the light.
The tangle of honeysuckle vines on
the slopes by the quadrangle showed
myriad clusters of spun glass. The
boardwalk itself sparkled as if
strewn with diamond dust, and the
whole 'atmosphere flashed with the
falling sleet, each particle a separate
sparkle.
Perhaps the most striking scene
of all was that from the top of the
bowl looking down upon Charles
street—a poem in silver and gold.
Every tree, down to its slenderest
twig, was completely encased in
shining sleet. Th warm yellow of
the street lamps—a succession of
gold crsytal-balls, stretching away
in perspective—lighted up_ these
trees in a blaze of unearthly splendor. They shone with brilliant
transparency, each branch and twig
a miracle of fragile and delicate
beauty.
Intermittently, electric flashes from
the copper wire of the car-line sent
shafts of blue fire through the crystal limbs of the ice-trees and made
the glistening streets flash purple.
Such a mood reaches the height
of a dream—all tiOness vanishes as
if by magic, and beauty, though
short-lived, holds undisputed sway.
R. K.

With the football season practically over, the "hot stove league"
is now in full blast. Demon mathematicians are diligently sharpening
lead pencils to figure out such vital
statistics as the average number of
touchdowns made by the teams in
the Rocky Mountain district; sporting editors are scanning box scores
in an effort to compile All-American, All-Maryland or All-Baltimore
elevens; while other experts are
frantically trying to determine who
tile various section champions are.

The statisticians discovered that
138 college teams, playing 1,180
games, scored 18,015 points. There
was a noticeable decline in scoring
Points after touchdowns, 38 games
being decided by the margin of one
Point. The average :total season
scoring for each team totaled 130.5
Points, and for each game 15.3
Points.
Several noteworthy performances
are recorded in the matter of making extra points. Paul- Scull of
Pennsylvania sent• five consecutive
kicks over the crossbars in the PennCornell battle. The outstanding
Player in this particular branch of
the game was Filbert of Roanoke,
Who scored 15 consecutive goals
after touchdown.

Much grumbling has been heard
On all sides concerning the football
r.tiles of the past season. The moving back of the goal posts has almost eliminated the field goal as a
means of scoring. Such an exhibition of drop-kicking as that shown
at Baltimore in the Army-Navy
game several years ago would have
been almost an impossibility during
the past season.
The peculiar forward-passing
rules have also been the source of

WHITE LECTURES ON
CENTRAL AMERICA
Says Future of Region Lies in
Agricultural Progress
"The salvation of the internal regions of Central America lies in the
development of its agricultural possibilities," stated Mr. P. R. White,
of the Johns Hopkins department
of botany, in his illustrated lecture
on "Central America," delivered last
Tuesday in the Civil Engineering
Building. Air. White has spent a
great deal of his time during the
past two years in Cuba, Jamaica,
Costa Rica and Panama, doing special work for the United Fruit Company, which, with the Firestone
Rubber Company, has established
an experimental plantation in the
interior of Central America.

ANCIENT POCKET ALMANAC FORMS
BASIS FOR NEXT ISSUE OF BLUE JAY
The "Almanac Number" of the
Black and Blue Jay is scheduled to
make its appearance on the campus about one week before Christmas. A wealth of material is expected to be uncovered in an old
almanac which one of the candidates has contributed in order to
furnish original ideas for the December issue of Hopkins' wellknown comic. This almanac, which
has been in the possession of the
candidate's family for about a hundred years, is a small pocket-sized
paper-back publication of the type

so familiar to our forefathers.
Naturally, it is highly prized because of its age and peculiar interest as one of the few surviving examples of a largely extinct type of
literary effort. The lender has requested that it be carefully preserved.
In addition to the almanac idea,
the forthcoming Jay will contain
the usual jokes, clever cuts and an
editorial by Donald White, editorin-chief. The advertising staff has
been working hard on its assignment and several neW full-page ads
are expected to be included.

No Mineral Resources

Mr. White bases the above assertion on the fact that there are practically no mineral or industrial resources in Central America. There
is neither coal nor oil. The rivers
contain water only during the rainy
season. The only profitable undertakings are agriculture and the
leather industry. At present ttle
United Fruit Company is reclaiming swamps and building railroads
and plantations as a part of its
scheme for the development of Central America.
The pictures which Mr. White exhibited and explained were taken
by himself. They covered his voyage from New York and his travels
through Panama, Costa Rica and
Jamaica, in addition to some small
islands which he visited. Mr. White
pointed out that these regions would
doubtless prove very fruitful to
future scientific expeditions, being
of especial interest to botanists, zoologists and geologists.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 9, 1927

COMMITTEE CLEARS
ON RECENT RAFFLE
Twenty-five dollars was
cleared by the 1928 June
Week Committee from the
proceeds of the raffle held recently, stated David Kaufman,
treasurer of the committee.
Fifty-five dollars in chances
were sold, and expenses totalled thirty dollars.
Several more raffles will be
held this year. The idea is
not so much to make money as
to keep up the interest of the
undergraduates in June Week.
The next chances will probably be sold after the Christmas holidays.

BASKETBALL MEETING
IS WELL ATTENDED
48 Candidates Sign up for New
Winter Sport; Schedule
Being Arranged
Forty-eight candidates for Hopkins' latest sport turned out at the
basketball organization meeting held
Tuesday in the Mechanical Engineering Hall. Speeches and a discussion of prospects for a success
ful season formed the program.
Dr. Van Orman, Gardner Mallonee, and Fred Bauernschmidt addressed the candidates. Mallonee
stressed the fact that .the team must
be supported, or else this year will
be the last for the winter sport.
Basketball is merely being tried this
year, and the support of the entire
student body is necessary to make it
permanent.
The names of candidates for the
team as well as those who are out
for manager were taken. Nearly
fifty men signed up• for the team;
seven signified their intention of trying for the managership.
It is planned tentatively to play
games on Tuesday and Friday evenings. The season, it is expected,
will open sometime in January.

Dr. Ray Van Orman will
not leave Hopkins to coach

Jays Will Not Meet Delaware or

Swarthmore and Randolph-Macon will replace Loyola and Delaware on the 1928 football schedule.
According to an announcement
made by Frederick Bauernschmidt,
manager of football, eight games
will be played.

Richmond First

With the release by the Registrar's Office of the number of registrations made on the opening days
of the University this year, some interesting facts have come to light.
The enrollment is smaller this
year than last in the School of
Business Economics. and the College of Arts and Sciences, appreciably so in the latter. The New
Plan, no doubt, is the cause of the
decrease in the College enrollment.
While last year was one of high enrollment in the Economics Department, because of the closing of that
same branch at the University of
Maryland, it is only natural that
there should be something of a decrease this year.
The School of Engineering, however, was able to show a substantial
increase in the number of enrollments over those of last year, there
being no causes but those of natural
growth affecting it at this time.
The Faculty of Philosophy also
shows quite an upward trend in the
number of members_ enrolled, many
of them having been gained at the
expense of the College of Arts and
Sciences through the New Plan.
Many Southerners Of the entire membership of the
Faculty of Philosophy, 70 per cent
are from Southern States, 18 per
cent from Northern and Western
States and the remaining 12 per
cent from foreign countries, ranging from Poland and Russia
through Palestine and South Africa
to China.
But 4 per cent of the undergraduates studying in the School of
Business Economics are from the
North, and no foreigners are present.
In the College of Arts and Sciences, 77 per cent come from the
South, 20 per cent from the North
and West and 3 per cent are foreigners. The Engineers have a
great number of students from below the Mason-Dixon Line, 93 per
cent of the entire number being
from the South, 5 per cent coming
from the North and West, and the
remaining 2 per cent coming from
outside the United States.

Thirty athletic awards were made
by the Athletic Board in recognition of services rendered during the
past two months. Fourteen varsity

football, and six "cHc's" for members of the cross-country team were
made.
Captain Mallonee, Leibensperger,
Kaufman, Biddison, Kegan, Houston, Strade.r, Boynton, Lyons, Lawrence, Caplan, Pindell, Ahroon and
Schmiedicke are the men who received the varsity "H" for football.
The letter was awarded to Ahroon
and Schmiedicke as recognition of
their faithful services during the
past four seasons. Neither of these
men had played a sufficient amount
of time to be awarded a letter on
that basis; but their loyalty and
spirit was such that, on the strong
recommendation of both Dr. Van
Orman and Captain Mallonee, the
Athletic Association Board awarded

Minor Awards

men who have participated in a few
games but who have not played a
sufficient length of time to win the
major "H."
Captain Schiebel, Gwinn, Kelly,
Waters, Wheeler and Emerson are
the men who won the "cHc" for
their endeavors on the cross-country team. The election of Robert
Kelly as captain of the cross-country team for the 1928 season was
officially recognized by the Board.
The new record for the Homewood
course, of 22 minutes, 59 seconds,
set by Dick Gwinn, was also given
official sanction.

DO THEY REALLY WANT BASKETBALL?
If the number of candidates for basketball is indicative of anything, the team should get off to a good start. Of course, the fact
that some fifty men are hopeful of making the team does hot
necessarily mean that there will be even five excellent basketball
players among the lot, but it does mean, we believe, that the
student body wants basketball.
Now, whether the team will receive the "moral" support of
the student body at the games is a problem that is probably keeping some of our alumni awake at nights. Will the games be
well attended? Would the sport prosper, though, if the team
should lose its first two or three games? The opinion has been
expressed on the campus that the success of the team, as far as
the support of the student body is concerned, depends upon its
winning the first few games. If it appears as though the team
will be a good one, it is argued, the fickle student body will
support it; if not, there will be little or no interest evinced in it.
We want to .warn against this point of view before it gains
headway. Of course, we like to be optimistic, but it can hardly
be expected that a team organized for the first time, and, moreover,
comparatively late in the season, will win the State championship.
If it wins more than half of its games, it will be doing exceedingly well. We hope, therefore, that the apparent enthusiasm for
the new sport is not caused merely by the novelty. Though there
are no goal posts to tear down, there are still ways of supporting
a team.

Moods.
We all have them—dark, gray,
sullen, sour, light, merry, funereal.
They come and go unheralded and
in no particular order. They are
miscellaneous.
So with the Hopkins campus.
Like humans, its moods are manifold, and Gilman Hall, not yet old
enough to wear the unruffled dignity
of venerable aristocracy, readily reflects the changes in temperament.
On windy days in autumn the
campus takes on a frolicsome air
It radiates mischief. Leaves, crisp
and sere, scurry pell mell in high
glee before the wind. Whole battalions of them race about like mad
in ecstatic confusion. Pieces of
paper and other movab!es, lying
about, abrubtly come to life and
dance about in frisky fashion. Little whirlwinds and eddies of air
suddenly spring up and go gamboling off into nothingness. And the
chimes in Gilman tower ring with
a merrier note as roguish blasts play
outlandish pranks with fall styles
in co-ed apparel.
Sometimes the spirit of the campus is dull—duller than dirt, full of
dusty answers. Such is its complexion on a steaming day in midsummer, when inactivity charges
the very atmosphere with stolid oppression. The face on the clock
looks bored and somehow at a loss.
Often the change in mood on
such days is sudden. A thunderstorm gathers in the west and begins to descend like a scourge, whipping things into action as it comes.
The air suddenly bristles with energy, becomes electric. The tower
looks frightened, standing sharp out
in startling relief against the menacing gun metal hue of the clouds.
Inertia gives place to taut expectancy, as a distant rumbling rolls
a warning. The storm breaks and
Homewood quivers under the lash
of rain and lightning. Thus quickly
in life may dullness change to action.
Oftentimes, on cold rainy days,
the lead of the skies sinks its heavy
pall, and gloom sits brooding on
the chimney tops of Gilman Hall.
Slow, drizzling rain falls in mournful silence and black depression
reigns in sad state, like a corpse in
evening dress.
Such conventional moods at

Homewood are well known and frequent. It remains for a sleet storm,
such as the recent phenomenon, to
make the campus temporarily a
region of rare fantastic loveliness.
All day last Sunday rain and
sleet had fallen and accumulated
in freezing, so that by evening
Homewood shone with an eerie and
amazing beauty. The warm light
within the clock tower of Gilman
Hall partially illuminated the flashing ice-glazed front of the building and shed a soft reflection out
on the smooth, glassy surface of the
quadrangle.
The campus became a wonderland of crystal, in which every object, however small, received its individual coating of ice. Railings,
door-knobs, the iron grating of the
gates of Gilman tunnel, the posts,
the steps—all shared in the general
transformation.
Smooth sheets of silver marked
the location of the tennis courts,
and the wire fences enclosing them
were networks of crystal.
The hedges, gleaming under the
boardwalk lamps, turned countless
leaves of clearest glass to the light.
The tangle of honeysuckle vines on
the slopes by the quadrangle showed
myriad clusters of spun glass. The
boardwalk itself sparkled as if
strewn with diamond dust, and the
whole 'atmosphere flashed with the
falling sleet, each particle a separate
sparkle.
Perhaps the most striking scene
of all was that from the top of the
bowl looking down upon Charles
street—a poem in silver and gold.
Every tree, down to its slenderest
twig, was completely encased in
shining sleet. Th warm yellow of
the street lamps—a succession of
gold crsytal-balls, stretching away
in perspective—lighted up_ these
trees in a blaze of unearthly splendor. They shone with brilliant
transparency, each branch and twig
a miracle of fragile and delicate
beauty.
Intermittently, electric flashes from
the copper wire of the car-line sent
shafts of blue fire through the crystal limbs of the ice-trees and made
the glistening streets flash purple.
Such a mood reaches the height
of a dream—all tiOness vanishes as
if by magic, and beauty, though
short-lived, holds undisputed sway.

With the football season practically over, the "hot stove league"
is now in full blast. Demon mathematicians are diligently sharpening
lead pencils to figure out such vital
statistics as the average number of
touchdowns made by the teams in
the Rocky Mountain district; sporting editors are scanning box scores
in an effort to compile All-American, All-Maryland or All-Baltimore
elevens; while other experts are
frantically trying to determine who
tile various section champions are.

The statisticians discovered that
138 college teams, playing 1,180
games, scored 18,015 points. There
was a noticeable decline in scoring
Points after touchdowns, 38 games
being decided by the margin of one
Point. The average :total season
scoring for each team totaled 130.5
Points, and for each game 15.3
Points.
Several noteworthy performances
are recorded in the matter of making extra points. Paul- Scull of
Pennsylvania sent• five consecutive
kicks over the crossbars in the PennCornell battle. The outstanding
Player in this particular branch of
the game was Filbert of Roanoke,
Who scored 15 consecutive goals
after touchdown.

WHITE LECTURES ON
CENTRAL AMERICA
Says Future of Region Lies in
Agricultural Progress
"The salvation of the internal regions of Central America lies in the
development of its agricultural possibilities," stated Mr. P. R. White,
of the Johns Hopkins department
of botany, in his illustrated lecture
on "Central America," delivered last
Tuesday in the Civil Engineering
Building. Air. White has spent a
great deal of his time during the
past two years in Cuba, Jamaica,
Costa Rica and Panama, doing special work for the United Fruit Company, which, with the Firestone
Rubber Company, has established
an experimental plantation in the
interior of Central America.

ANCIENT POCKET ALMANAC FORMS
BASIS FOR NEXT ISSUE OF BLUE JAY
The "Almanac Number" of the
Black and Blue Jay is scheduled to
make its appearance on the campus about one week before Christmas. A wealth of material is expected to be uncovered in an old
almanac which one of the candidates has contributed in order to
furnish original ideas for the December issue of Hopkins' wellknown comic. This almanac, which
has been in the possession of the
candidate's family for about a hundred years, is a small pocket-sized
paper-back publication of the type

so familiar to our forefathers.
Naturally, it is highly prized because of its age and peculiar interest as one of the few surviving examples of a largely extinct type of
literary effort. The lender has requested that it be carefully preserved.
In addition to the almanac idea,
the forthcoming Jay will contain
the usual jokes, clever cuts and an
editorial by Donald White, editorin-chief. The advertising staff has
been working hard on its assignment and several neW full-page ads
are expected to be included.

Power Show Held

One of the principal points of interest was the Sixth National Exposition of Power and Mechanical
Engineering, known as the Power
Show, held in the Grand Central
Palace. There are over 400 booths
in this very large exhibition of various machines and processes of machinofacture. The Power Show
lasts all this week.
In the A. S. M. E. meeting Monday was devoted to business affairs
and conferences of local section
delegates, Baltimore being represented by Professor Kouwenhoven,
secretary of the district. Various
discussions and readings of papers
occupied most of the remaining
days.

Three Professors at
Engineering Meeting
Professors Alexander Christie
and Frank Kouwenhoven returned
yesterday from New York, where
they attended the annual meeting
of the American Society of • Mechanical Engineers. The meeting
was held from Monday to Thursday of this week at the New York
headquarters of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers on
39th St. Professor Julian Smallwood also attended one day of the
meeting.

No Mineral Resources

Mr. White bases the above assertion on the fact that there are practically no mineral or industrial resources in Central America. There
is neither coal nor oil. The rivers
contain water only during the rainy
season. The only profitable undertakings are agriculture and the
leather industry. At present ttle
United Fruit Company is reclaiming swamps and building railroads
and plantations as a part of its
scheme for the development of Central America.
The pictures which Mr. White exhibited and explained were taken
by himself. They covered his voyage from New York and his travels
through Panama, Costa Rica and
Jamaica, in addition to some small
islands which he visited. Mr. White
pointed out that these regions would
doubtless prove very fruitful to
future scientific expeditions, being
of especial interest to botanists, zoologists and geologists.
